With the new update, the game has really upped its... game (snort). It’s much improved, but only relative to its ease to start with. There are legit unresolved problems that even the new update didn’t address, and are probably keeping the more inexperienced off of their doorstep. It's difficult because I really want to give this game a shot- but I've spent over two hours messing around with the game and lobby settings, and haven't even been able to blow anything up. I really need some direction for me to recommend this game, but for now it's too undeveloped for me to stick a “yes” on it.UPDATE 5/4/14I'm holding true to my promise that I would update this further.So, this review has been getting reviewed pretty good. It attracted enough attention that even the developer came to my page! (This was my initial impression, before realizing that every negative review on the game was downvoted by this individual.)To start, the first thing even close to help I received was the developer finding my review and labeling me as “not using my noggin” when dealing with in-game commands. I'm not holding grudges, our issues are resolved. However, nothing is laid out, and the service I've received by a helpful community member (and only a community member, that is, someone not responsible to the game itself) has been the only clarification. The lobby is scary, in-game less so, and it's all expected to be figured out by the player, as made evident by the developer. Apparently it was not just me who wasn't able to build something so simple as generators, which was seen as obvious and common sense during development and doesn't require explanation (however, the developer did design a very helpful piece of video tutorial, just for me, that can be found in the comments or here: http://www.twitch.tv/evolutionrts/b/524601270 – I feel loved).So the service is garbage, if I can sum it up.Shout-out to Paladin, for the help I did get. :)--ORIGINAL TEXT-- 4/8/14Note: This is not a review of the gameplay itself, and you'll find out why in a second.The download for the game is simply a download for a game lobby.OH GOD WHY.I hung around for around 25 minutes trying to figure out how to just start a game. The Terms of Service for the Spring Engine lobby were easy to read, props for that. Other than that, there was no documentation/instructions for  getting you familiar/set up/started, and the layout of the lobby featured tabs and whatnot that remained completely unexplained because of it. Apparently I needed to downoad game files from an obscure site location to start a game. I found this out after I made a feeble attempt at starting a match. DENIED. What's even worse is that, for some reason, you have to join a multiplayer game to get the downlaods available to you. If this all sounds vague, it's because it was. I chatted with another equally confused player (probably from Steam as well) who was just about to head out when I beat him to the door.Granted, I would need longer to experiment with the lobby and learn how to start a game, but that was time I didn't have (a LOT of time I don't have). I instead spent my time writing a review. So there.Overall, gameplay not included, this is not designed for casual gamers who do not posess preobtained knowledge of how game lobbies work. This game won't be worth it to me until the setup is unobscured and clarified.

												In simple terms, if you have played supreme commander and liked it, you will absolutely like this as well.However, if you did not enjoy playing supreme commander or despise micromanagement RTS games, this isn't for you.For those who are interested, some free tips upon joining the game...First, what you are downloading from steam is just a server platform. Not the game itself.Secondly, once you join a server room (in the multiplayer tab, duh!), you are automatically allocated as a spectator. You will not be allowed to pick a team and play until you have downloaded the game contents and its map for the particular match (all of which will be done for you automatically so do not worry, just wait a bit once you've joined).Thirdly, after you have completed the download process, join a team or create a team.Lastly, click start and enjoy. It will play the same way as supreme commander so it will come to you naturally. Only difference is that the buildings and units names are different.My final advice for newcomers - Join as a spectator and take a look at how others play. You have free movement as a spectator.

												Free and open source. Evolution RTS does everything right. It runs very smoothly, has very nice music that as far as I can tell from other reviews is somehow being dynamically generated. The units look a little bit samey from a distance, just different looking SCV-ish looking robots. Upon zooming in however you do realize that they are indeed varied and have varied robotic exoskeletons. The graphics are effective although it could still compel more more immersion by adding more scenery elements and whatnot. There really is no reason for you not to have this into your library. It is a fine addition... except for one thing...It somehow manages to feel extremely generic still, I do not know who I am controlling, why I am fighting, I do not know what the unit does, how the tech tree is meant to work, and a lot of numbers are on screen I am not sure which are metal and which are energy, or why I am making those thingies in the ground. It was more or less painless for me to use the lobby to make a single player game but after scouting around with a random robot army sustained by my low supply count and not finding the AI... I simply was too disengaged to really invest more time in it. This game would strongly benefit from single player scenarios that give context, introduce the player the game's concepts, and give some reason to idenfify, care, and have fun. A lot of the fun from strategy games is the sense of control you end up having from implementing strategies and seeing their outcome and I am sure that with a basic storyline, with gradual introduction of units it would be a lot more immersive. And maybe make the rest of the lobby and the multiplayer components separate from it. A simple artwork menu with Tutorial, Single player, Multiplayer buttons goes a long way.In any case I do think this is at least a 6 out of 10. It looks average, but it could become much much much more. And since it is free and open source it should be treated as greater than average. I'll come back to the game in the future and see how it came along. In the meantime I will catch up on playing some of those other RTS's I own that have all I mentionned and that I never got to play or finish.

												Evolution RTS is one of many RTS built on the Spring engine. It's also one of the more casual games in the bunch.For me it is much less stressful than your average RTS. Battles are relatively quick, fun, and flashy. It may share some similarities with other games in the TA vein, but it is not nearly as long winded as some can get.It has some rough edges, yes, but give it time. It is very  playable as is but with the amount of feedback it's getting  (more than ever before) it will be even better shortly. Forboding Angel (the main dev) is a dedicated individual and I'm sure he is loving the chance to make a game you can also easily enjoy.As a side note: If you're an RTS fan and this game didn't catch your fancy; Turn off the filter in the match lobby to check out the other spring RTS games. One of them might be what you're looking for.

												TLDR "Free or Not your time is better spent on literally anything else"Evolution RTS is a free real time strategy game based on the open source Spring engine.  The Spring engine was originally created as part of the TA Spring project which sought to bring Chris Taylor’s cult RTS “Total Annihilation” into full 3D.  Spring has since spawn a myriad of new games from TA inspired RTS games to a WWII RTS boasting multiple factions and 300 unique units. Evolution RTS uses the Spring Lobby to setup single player and multiplayer matches. So not unlike steam games with DRM from the publisher or developer launching Evolution RTS does not start the game but actually launches the Spring Lobby which acts as a platform for playing spring engine games. During the initial Steam Release of Evolution this caused a lot of confusion since clicking “play game” didn’t actually install or even launch the game.  Obviously this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off a few steam users who got lost trying to navigate Spring Lobby to play the game.  It’s the same complaint that is leveled at DRM software like U-play (Spring Lobby is not DRM), it puts an unnecessary layer between the user and the game.  Certainly it doesn’t fit within the framework of the Steam platform where uses expect the game to launch from their Steam library page.Fortunately, the developers took steps to rectify the issue by having steam load Evolution RTS and some if its popular maps in addition to the Spring Lobby. Unfortunately this still leaves users with a barrier: Spring Lobby itself. Spring Lobby isn’t terribly unintuitive and anyone with moderate computer skills should have no issues navigating it despite the fact that some UI elements are missing good tooltips. It does however move like a worm through bedrock.  It took me several minutes to setup a single player AI bot match because the interface would simply freeze each time I tried to add an AI and then again when I’d change the AI’s difficult. I honestly thought I wasn’t going to be able to pick a map, but then I typed the first few letters of the maps name and was able to select it.  The drop down menu doesn’t appear to work.  The gameplay is obviously inspired by Total Annihilation.  It uses a dual streaming resource system requiring metal and energy to construct units and buildings It deviates a bit in adding a supply system.  The game currently has a lot of the staples from the “TA Genre” including radar, land, air, and amphibious units, nukes, super units etc. but unfortunately there is only one faction to pick meaning each match feels a bit like a mirror.Each game starts by selecting your start position.  I choose the top right corner of the map badlands because it looks like there is a lot of metal there.  I press ready and get a count down.  I start with one unit the “Overseer” which I use to construct some basic economy buildings.  The art assets, the graphics, and the animations all feel dated.  The Spring engine is no spring chicken, but there are other Spring offerings which do a far more serviceable job. Once I build my factory I get the first sign of something wrong: all my offensive units are in red like I cannot construct any of them despite having available resources.  I am unsure if this is a bug or not, but I had to restart the game 3 times before I was finally able to construct units.  In every match I played the AI parked its Overseer or commander unit in the middle of the map and never moved it when I attacked.  Fortunately it appears the AI actually knows how to build and attack.All buildings are available for construction from the start of the game.  There doesn’t appear to be any research, upgrade, or tier system.  The constructor units don’t get an “advanced factory” to build.  Unfortunately the bad unit and building design makes this freedom pointless, I have no desire to see what units I can build.Combat doesn’t thrill me either.  The sounds (when you can hear them over the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dubstep soundtrack) are pretty generic, the units explode leaving no wreckage. Units don’t seem to have much in the way of hit points meaning your army won’t last very long before exploding.  .  I tried building defensive towers but found them destroyed quickly by even light scout units.  It’s obvious the game lacks any semblance of balance.  At this point in my play through I couldn’t handle another minute of the soundtrack which felt completely out of place in an RTS game, but right at home in a 12 year olds Call of Duty video.  When I saw that the options menu was devoid of any content and I couldn’t shut off the direct feed to some wannabe-skrillex’s soundcloud page.  I had to stop.Do not play this game. Amateur doesn’t even describe it, early access doesn’t describe, it isn’t worth the 5 – 10 minutes it takes to set it up.  Free or not pass on this one.  If you’re feeling nostalgic about Chris Taylor RTS games there are plenty of better Spring offerings, TA on GOG, and an active community around SupCom FA called FA Forever. If you’re looking for fresh RTS blood move along, you won’t find that here either.  To anyone who says why are you knocking a free game?  Well because the developers are offering it to people as a way to spend their free time.  This is a commodity as much as money is.  Trust me on this oneYour free time is better spent elsewhere.

												Evolution RTS feels very unfinished, there is a reason for this. The game fails to explain what you need to do to make units work. The graphics are fine for an RTS game.The AI of your units is the only thing keeping them in combat until you figure out the attack system which the game does not tell you about, if you don't force them to attack, they just sit looking at the thing you told them to attack, making air units near useless. The lack of a reload time indicator makes bombers extremely underpowered as you have no idea when to force the next attack and it appears that when you do, the timer resets.The AI players are based on tower defense or survival games meaning that the AI constantly throws unit at you, and you have to defend. On both games I have played with AI players, the AI on my team appeared to do nothing but the truth is that it was spawning units to fight the spawned units of the enemy!The description of this game states that it fits ALL skill levels. 												TLDR "Free or Not your time is better spent on literally anything else"Evolution RTS is a free real time strategy game based on the open source Spring engine.  The Spring engine was originally created as part of the TA Spring project which sought to bring Chris Taylor’s cult RTS “Total Annihilation” into full 3D.  Spring has since spawn a myriad of new games from TA inspired RTS games to a WWII RTS boasting multiple factions and 300 unique units. Evolution RTS uses the Spring Lobby to setup single player and multiplayer matches. So not unlike steam games with DRM from the publisher or developer launching Evolution RTS does not start the game but actually launches the Spring Lobby which acts as a platform for playing spring engine games. During the initial Steam Release of Evolution this caused a lot of confusion since clicking “play game” didn’t actually install or even launch the game.  Obviously this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off a few steam users who got lost trying to navigate Spring Lobby to play the game.  It’s the same complaint that is leveled at DRM software like U-play (Spring Lobby is not DRM), it puts an unnecessary layer between the user and the game.  Certainly it doesn’t fit within the framework of the Steam platform where uses expect the game to launch from their Steam library page.Fortunately, the developers took steps to rectify the issue by having steam load Evolution RTS and some if its popular maps in addition to the Spring Lobby. Unfortunately this still leaves users with a barrier: Spring Lobby itself. Spring Lobby isn’t terribly unintuitive and anyone with moderate computer skills should have no issues navigating it despite the fact that some UI elements are missing good tooltips. It does however move like a worm through bedrock.  It took me several minutes to setup a single player AI bot match because the interface would simply freeze each time I tried to add an AI and then again when I’d change the AI’s difficult. I honestly thought I wasn’t going to be able to pick a map, but then I typed the first few letters of the maps name and was able to select it.  The drop down menu doesn’t appear to work.  The gameplay is obviously inspired by Total Annihilation.  It uses a dual streaming resource system requiring metal and energy to construct units and buildings It deviates a bit in adding a supply system.  The game currently has a lot of the staples from the “TA Genre” including radar, land, air, and amphibious units, nukes, super units etc. but unfortunately there is only one faction to pick meaning each match feels a bit like a mirror.Each game starts by selecting your start position.  I choose the top right corner of the map badlands because it looks like there is a lot of metal there.  I press ready and get a count down.  I start with one unit the “Overseer” which I use to construct some basic economy buildings.  The art assets, the graphics, and the animations all feel dated.  The Spring engine is no spring chicken, but there are other Spring offerings which do a far more serviceable job. Once I build my factory I get the first sign of something wrong: all my offensive units are in red like I cannot construct any of them despite having available resources.  I am unsure if this is a bug or not, but I had to restart the game 3 times before I was finally able to construct units.  In every match I played the AI parked its Overseer or commander unit in the middle of the map and never moved it when I attacked.  Fortunately it appears the AI actually knows how to build and attack.All buildings are available for construction from the start of the game.  There doesn’t appear to be any research, upgrade, or tier system.  The constructor units don’t get an “advanced factory” to build.  Unfortunately the bad unit and building design makes this freedom pointless, I have no desire to see what units I can build.Combat doesn’t thrill me either.  The sounds (when you can hear them over the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dubstep soundtrack) are pretty generic, the units explode leaving no wreckage. Units don’t seem to have much in the way of hit points meaning your army won’t last very long before exploding.  .  I tried building defensive towers but found them destroyed quickly by even light scout units.  It’s obvious the game lacks any semblance of balance.  At this point in my play through I couldn’t handle another minute of the soundtrack which felt completely out of place in an RTS game, but right at home in a 12 year olds Call of Duty video.  When I saw that the options menu was devoid of any content and I couldn’t shut off the direct feed to some wannabe-skrillex’s soundcloud page.  I had to stop.Do not play this game. Amateur doesn’t even describe it, early access doesn’t describe, it isn’t worth the 5 – 10 minutes it takes to set it up.  Free or not pass on this one.  If you’re feeling nostalgic about Chris Taylor RTS games there are plenty of better Spring offerings, TA on GOG, and an active community around SupCom FA called FA Forever. If you’re looking for fresh RTS blood move along, you won’t find that here either.  To anyone who says why are you knocking a free game?  Well because the developers are offering it to people as a way to spend their free time.  This is a commodity as much as money is.  Trust me on this oneYour free time is better spent elsewhere.
